channel.title: 华尔街日报热门
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: Drug-enforcement agents seized 1.8 million fake pills laced with the synthetic opioid fentanyl and arrested more than 800 people across the U.S. in a crackdown on online sales of the potentially deadly drugs https://t.co/uNbYqPK5Ig
A Covid-19 surge in Maine has filled hospitals and put dozens of mostly unvaccinated people on ventilators, setting records for the state https://t.co/lz0KaDwxer

The U.S. government is set to let as many as 80,000 employment-based green cards expire Friday, leaving foreign workers waiting for a permanent resolution to their immigration limbo https://t.co/qiwbMfvkAw

Gun maker Smith & Wesson is moving its corporate headquarters from Massachusetts to Tennessee, joining other firearms manufacturers that have moved to Southern states with less restrictive gun laws https://t.co/Vb6YehKbg0

A pregnant woman didn't know the hospital where she was about to give birth was fighting a ransomware attack. Her baby was in distress, and later died. Are the hackers or the hospital to blame? https://t.co/VAjiqffTvT

Sen. Blumenthal wanted to see what life was like on Instagram for teens, so his office set up an account that identified as a 13-year-old girl. Within a day, Instagram had served up content that promoted eating disorders and self injury, he said. https://t.co/CqUy5Huolh

The Kīlauea volcano in Hawaii started erupting, creating lava flows within the 4,000-foot summit, with the U.S. Geological Survey’s Hawaiian Volcano Observatory saying high levels of volcanic gas are the primary hazard of concern https://t.co/LCr5gpNn6B

Dozens of federal judges have heard cases involving companies in which they or their family owned stock. But none more so than Rodney Gilstrap, a judge in East Texas who didn’t recuse himself 138 times in such cases since 2011. https://t.co/e4R26kvzua
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/2S0jE4Pqw3 https://t.co/FhXtu9Svqv

A Los Angeles Superior Court judge granted Britney Spears’s request to remove her father as conservator of her $60 million estate, putting the pop star a step closer to reclaiming control over her finances #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/mMie6X1M7i

Najla Bouden Romdhane, a professor at a Tunisian university, became the country’s first woman prime minister, with the task of forming a stable government after weeks of turmoil https://t.co/tvhYuB76qY

A couple's property in Iceland has views of an extinct volcano, the top of the country’s second-largest glacier and something less common: lush, green surroundings. “This place is like walking into a green haven.” https://t.co/33y7M1rHyc

Dozens of federal judges have heard cases involving companies in which they or their family owned stock. But none more so than Rodney Gilstrap, a judge in East Texas who didn’t recuse himself 138 times in such cases since 2011. https://t.co/9nfeJQKeC6

The biggest U.S. companies are sitting on record piles of cash. They are getting paid next to nothing for holding it, and they are running out of ways to spend it. So they are buying a lot of commercial real estate. https://t.co/5rOvO7ZgzL
From @WSJopinion: OSHA’s job is to promote safe workplaces, not to dictate medical decisions to employees, write @DavidRivkin and Robert Alt https://t.co/zHVqKkeJiu

The Biden administration is moving to restore criminal penalties for accidental killings of migratory birds, saying the measures are needed to protect declining bird populations https://t.co/kIBThfn7t3

In the biggest batch announced yet, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service has classified 23 endangered species as extinct, and is proposing removing them from the Endangered Species Act https://t.co/vCKGsKwaSp

Dollar Tree plans to sell products at $1.25 and $1.50 or other prices slightly above $1 in some of its stores, as supply-chain snarls, a tight labor market and inflation push costs higher https://t.co/VwURzSBpiF
Bishops in the U.S. and Germany are poised to challenge Pope Francis on abortion and gay rights, in tests that could determine the 84-year-old’s legacy https://t.co/BFQeS7FGJp

From @WSJopinion: Biden hopes the political fallout from his botched Afghanistan withdrawal will fade quickly, but Tuesday’s Senate hearing with the secretary of Defense and two top generals doesn’t cast his decisions in a better light https://t.co/S1apogKp79
Breaking: Britney Spears’s father has been suspended as conservator of her $60 million estate after a 13-year arrangement that the singer called abusive https://t.co/cuNMR5zSJI

Billionaire Ken Griffin’s electronic trading firm, Citadel Securities, is under fire again over its role in the January trading frenzy in shares of GameStop after new information surfaced in a lawsuit https://t.co/qRHrSETjfy
The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service said the ivory-billed woodpecker and 22 other endangered species are extinct https://t.co/EaNvtVOUEb

Dozens of federal judges have heard cases involving companies in which they or their family owned stock. But none more so than Rodney Gilstrap, a judge in East Texas who didn’t recuse himself 138 times in such cases since 2011. https://t.co/HXbeUDhqW7
Harvard Business School has moved most of its M.B.A. classes online following a spate of breakthrough Covid-19 infections among its students https://t.co/STre4qZ9Y2
Satellite images show the scale of the backlog at ports in California. The ongoing supply chain issues are now threatening holiday shopping plans. #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/cASNSHr3OK

YouTube said it will remove content that falsely alleges approved vaccines are dangerous, expanding the video platform’s efforts in curbing misinformation on Covid-19 to other vaccines https://t.co/Tt4nXKvnYy
Job seekers are considering a new addition to their résumés: Covid-19 vaccination status https://t.co/jzUs82eS7m
India is preparing to produce its own mRNA-based Covid-19 vaccine by the end of the year, in what would be a scientific breakthrough for the country https://t.co/H7JruqEpEm

Dollar Tree plans to sell products at $1.25 and $1.50 or other prices slightly above $1 in some of its stores, as supply-chain snarls, a tight labor market and inflation push costs higher https://t.co/lm24aVpAZU
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/kgpIYlyWE3 https://t.co/t9boA9mD02
Watch: How did Cardano’s Ada become one of the largest cryptocurrencies by market capitalization and how does it differ from Bitcoin? We explain https://t.co/wEkkabXv9v
A surge in toxic customers and poor behavior has prompted many restaurants to rethink the adage that the customer is always right https://t.co/Dt2hRufQQ0
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/5CUpXEOxNU https://t.co/B0xZnknnHb

Thousands of healthcare workers in New York lost their jobs Tuesday when a new vaccine mandate went into effect, forcing some nursing homes to stop admitting new patients and hospitals to warn of longer wait times https://t.co/JNTD60OebI

More than 130 federal judges have violated U.S. law and judicial ethics by overseeing court cases involving companies in which they or their family owned stock, a WSJ investigation found. Judges failed to recuse themselves from 685 such cases since 2010. https://t.co/Zd2Jb24ylv
From @WSJopinion: The rush to renewables causes severe energy price spikes and shortages. Biden’s policies would do the same in the U.S, writes @AllysiaFinley. https://t.co/fKFR0cEaVz
Japan’s next prime minister will be Fumio Kishida, who favors a strong alliance with the U.S. and is concerned about China’s military expansion https://t.co/Nj2uhVuJeA

Research on Chinese projects launched under President Xi Jinping’s international infrastructure-development program points to hidden debt, corruption scandals, labor violations and environmental risks https://t.co/tYRHjagrkE

More than 130 federal judges have violated U.S. law and judicial ethics by overseeing court cases involving companies in which they or their family owned stock, a WSJ investigation found. Judges failed to recuse themselves from 685 such cases since 2010. https://t.co/mYY0FNuqPJ

Dozens of federal judges broke the law by hearing cases involving companies in which they or their family owned stock. Use our interactive tool to search for the judges involved and find out whether their rulings favored their financial interests. https://t.co/ZaPmo7iAGN

CNN said it has restricted access to its Facebook pages in Australia following a ruling from that country’s high court that makes news organizations legally liable for comments on their Facebook posts https://t.co/7wIWXFetjl

Thousands of healthcare workers in New York lost their jobs Tuesday when a new vaccine mandate went into effect, forcing some nursing homes to stop admitting new patients and hospitals to warn of longer wait times https://t.co/8lxGM70KOF
United Airlines Holdings Inc. is moving ahead with plans to terminate close to 600 employees who didn’t meet its Covid-19 vaccination deadline, company officials said Tuesday https://t.co/lYlulc5jMa

Lego, which responded to the pandemic by shifting marketing budgets to its online channels but didn’t make any significant strategic changes, strengthened its position as the world’s largest toy maker https://t.co/u8DPo9J1Pq

In the race to build a cheaper and longer-range electric car, auto companies are pouring more money into solid-state battery technology. It has the potential to deliver faster charging times and make packs safer than lithium-ion batteries. https://t.co/x2lRp93TGf

Pent-up demand for in-person bingo has been so strong in some spots that security guards and good Samaritans struggle to keep peace at the door. “We’re not going in here if we’re going to fight.” https://t.co/1OgjE8cgXo

The Pentagon’s top military officer said the evacuation of Americans, Afghans and allies out of Kabul in the final weeks of the nation’s longest war was a logistical success but a strategic failure. “Strategically, the war was lost.” https://t.co/1XFoO6L3VE

From @WSJopinion: Biden makes his $3.5 trillion tax and spend plan sound like a safety net program for the poor rather than what it really is: a government subsidy engine for everyone including the affluent https://t.co/9WKBRU3u9A
Regulatory clearance of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine for young children may not come until November, according to a person familiar with the matter https://t.co/Hej3bNrMjn
